clusters.title: Europe mostly flat premarket amid French political crisis
clusters.neutral_headline: French Political Crisis Follows Prime Minister's Resignation
bullet_summary: An adviser to the president told reporters that Macron would "do the responsible thing" if no solution was found to end this political deadlock by Wednesday night
Reported by Reuters Top News, France24, BBC World and others

items.title: Europe mostly flat premarket amid French political crisis
items.standfirst: European stock indexes traded mostly flat during premarket hours on Tuesday after French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu resigned just a day after unveiling the new government, citing disagreements b...
items.content: European stock indexes traded mostly flat during premarket hours on Tuesday after French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu resigned just a day after unveiling the new government, citing disagreements b...

items.title: European stocks set for mixed open as French crisis weighs on sentiment
items.standfirst: LONDON — European stocks are expected to open mixed on Tuesday, with all eyes on France after the resignation of Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu plunged the country into a fresh political crisis. The U.K.'s FTSE index is expected to open slightly lower, Germany's DAX 0.2% higher, France's CAC 40…
items.content: LONDON — European stocks are expected to open mixed on Tuesday, with all eyes on France after the resignation of Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu plunged the country into a fresh political crisis. The U.K.'s FTSE index is expected to open slightly lower, Germany's DAX 0.2% higher, France's CAC 40…

items.title: Live: Former French PM Philippe says in favour of early presidential election amid political crisis
items.standfirst: France's outgoing Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu was to make a last-ditch effort Tuesday to rally cross-party support for a cabinet lineup to pull his country out of political deadlock as former French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe said he was in favour of an early presidential election. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.
items.content: France's outgoing Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu was to make a last-ditch effort Tuesday to rally cross-party support for a cabinet lineup to pull his country out of political deadlock as former French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe said he was in favour of an early presidential election. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

items.title: A '48-hour deadline and a final chance' for Lecornu after French PM resigns
items.standfirst: Reporting from outside the Élysée presidential palace, FRANCE 24's Clovis Casali says President Emmanuel Macron has given Sébastien Lecornu a 48-hour deadline to form a government. An adviser to the president told reporters that Macron would "do the responsible thing" if no solution was found to end this political deadlock by Wednesday night. "In other words, he could call for a snap parliamentary elections," notes Casali.
items.content: Reporting from outside the Élysée presidential palace, FRANCE 24's Clovis Casali says President Emmanuel Macron has given Sébastien Lecornu a 48-hour deadline to form a government. An adviser to the president told reporters that Macron would "do the responsible thing" if no solution was found to end this political deadlock by Wednesday night. "In other words, he could call for a snap parliamentary elections," notes Casali.

items.title: 'We must be grown-ups today': French MP Eléonore Caroit asserts it's 'our duty' to seek way forward
items.standfirst: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move plunged the country further into political crisis and left President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Eléonore Caroit, a member of President Emmanuel Macron’s Renaissance party and an MP for French citizens living abroad, tells FRANCE 24 that she does not support a call for snap elections. “Do I think it's going to be any different if we call for elections today? I'm afraid it won't be radically different," she notes. "What we're seeing is that we have a divided country with a divided representation, and it is our duty as MPs to actually find a way [forward].”
items.content: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move plunged the country further into political crisis and left President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Eléonore Caroit, a member of President Emmanuel Macron’s Renaissance party and an MP for French citizens living abroad, tells FRANCE 24 that she does not support a call for snap elections. “Do I think it's going to be any different if we call for elections today? I'm afraid it won't be radically different," she notes. "What we're seeing is that we have a divided country with a divided representation, and it is our duty as MPs to actually find a way [forward].”

items.title: 'French politics has always been baroque, but now it's playing out on the public stage'
items.standfirst: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move has plunged the country further into political crisis, leaving embattled French President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Lecornu is now the shortest-serving prime minister in the history of the Fifth Republic. French politics have been in disarray since 2024 snap elections. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Genie Godula welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.
items.content: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move has plunged the country further into political crisis, leaving embattled French President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Lecornu is now the shortest-serving prime minister in the history of the Fifth Republic. French politics have been in disarray since 2024 snap elections. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Genie Godula welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.

items.title: A mess of Macron's making? France in crisis as latest government falls in 14 hours
items.standfirst: Emmanuel Macron losing his third prime minister, in the 16 months since he dissolved parliament and lost ensuing snap elections. Sebastien Lecornu breaking a Fifth Republic record by lasting just 27 days as head of government.
items.content: Emmanuel Macron losing his third prime minister, in the 16 months since he dissolved parliament and lost ensuing snap elections. Sebastien Lecornu breaking a Fifth Republic record by lasting just 27 days as head of government.

items.title: France in fresh political crisis as PM Lecornu quits after 26 days
items.standfirst: Lecornu was asked by President Macron to stay on until Wednesday in a last-ditch attempt to achieve "stability" for the country.
items.content: Lecornu was asked by President Macron to stay on until Wednesday in a last-ditch attempt to achieve "stability" for the country.

items.title: France is in crisis but bond markets leave other governments at risk of meltdown too
items.standfirst: Investors rattled by resignation of French PM but country is not alone in trying to grapple with political mathsMacron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to avoid political crisisWhat happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what next?Sébastien Lecornu’s abrupt resignation as the French prime minister on Monday after less than a month in the role marked the latest clash between France’s stretched public finances and its polarised politics.Lecornu was the latest prime minister to try and fail to cobble together a package of spending cuts and tax rises that would pass muster in a parliament without a clear majority, and contain mounting bond market pressures. Continue reading...
items.content: Investors rattled by resignation of French PM but country is not alone in trying to grapple with political mathsMacron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to avoid political crisisWhat happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what next?Sébastien Lecornu’s abrupt resignation as the French prime minister on Monday after less than a month in the role marked the latest clash between France’s stretched public finances and its polarised politics.Lecornu was the latest prime minister to try and fail to cobble together a package of spending cuts and tax rises that would pass muster in a parliament without a clear majority, and contain mounting bond market pressures. Continue reading...

items.title: France's President Macron gives outgoing PM Lecornu one last chance
items.standfirst: France's new prime minister resigned on Monday after less than a month in office, sinking the country further into a political crisis and piling pressure on President Emmanuel Macron to find a way out of the deadlock. As a response, the President asked outgoing PM Lecornu to hold 'final talks' and attempt to solve the situation by Wednesday. Story by Marc Perelman.
items.content: France's new prime minister resigned on Monday after less than a month in office, sinking the country further into a political crisis and piling pressure on President Emmanuel Macron to find a way out of the deadlock. As a response, the President asked outgoing PM Lecornu to hold 'final talks' and attempt to solve the situation by Wednesday. Story by Marc Perelman.

items.title: France's Macron tasks outgoing PM Lecornu to hold final talks to stabilize country
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron has asked outgoing Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu to hold final talks by Wednesday evening with political parties to stabilise the country, Macron's office said on Monday. Earlier on Monday, Lecornu offered his and his newly formed government's resignation after allies and foes alike had threatened to topple the government. Deatails by FRANCE 24 reporter Clovis Casali.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron has asked outgoing Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu to hold final talks by Wednesday evening with political parties to stabilise the country, Macron's office said on Monday. Earlier on Monday, Lecornu offered his and his newly formed government's resignation after allies and foes alike had threatened to topple the government. Deatails by FRANCE 24 reporter Clovis Casali.

items.title: Macron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to resolve political crisis
items.standfirst: French president requests Sébastien Lecornu stay on for 48 hours after he quit complaining of ‘egos’Explainer: What happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what could happen next?Hours after France’s new prime minister resigned less than a month after he was appointed, Emmanuel Macron has asked him to stay on for two more days in a last-ditch effort to chart a way out of the country’s rapidly deepening political crisis.The French president on Monday evening gave Sébastien Lecornu – who had earlier become the third prime minister of the EU’s second-biggest economy to quit in a year – 48 hours to “conduct final negotiations … to define a platform for action and stability”. Continue reading...
items.content: French president requests Sébastien Lecornu stay on for 48 hours after he quit complaining of ‘egos’Explainer: What happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what could happen next?Hours after France’s new prime minister resigned less than a month after he was appointed, Emmanuel Macron has asked him to stay on for two more days in a last-ditch effort to chart a way out of the country’s rapidly deepening political crisis.The French president on Monday evening gave Sébastien Lecornu – who had earlier become the third prime minister of the EU’s second-biggest economy to quit in a year – 48 hours to “conduct final negotiations … to define a platform for action and stability”. Continue reading...

items.title: France: President Macron under pressure after fifth PM in two years resigns
items.standfirst: Prime minister Sébastien Lecornu has resigned, creating a political earthquake in France. Lecornu was Prime minister for under a month, and was the fifth to hold the post in two years. His resignation renewed the focus on France's President, Emmanuel Macron, who is under pressure to act to resolve the crisis, by either dissolving the National Assembly, like he did last year, or quitting himself. Story by Charlotte Lam and France 2.
items.content: Prime minister Sébastien Lecornu has resigned, creating a political earthquake in France. Lecornu was Prime minister for under a month, and was the fifth to hold the post in two years. His resignation renewed the focus on France's President, Emmanuel Macron, who is under pressure to act to resolve the crisis, by either dissolving the National Assembly, like he did last year, or quitting himself. Story by Charlotte Lam and France 2.

items.title: Macron under pressure to call parliamentary elections after French PM quits
items.standfirst: Sebastien Lecornu's resignation has come kind of completely out of the blue - and there doesn't seem to be an obvious reason for it.
items.content: Sebastien Lecornu's resignation has come kind of completely out of the blue - and there doesn't seem to be an obvious reason for it.

items.content: France's prime minister Sebastien Lecornu has resigned after just 27 days.

The resignation occurred shortly after the naming of a new government.
President Macron has given a 48-hour deadline to form a new government.
Former Prime Minister Philippe supports an early presidential election.
European stock indexes traded mostly flat amid the uncertainty.

clusters.title: Stranded Mount Everest hikers being evacuated
clusters.neutral_headline: Blizzard Strands Hundreds of Hikers on Mount Everest
bullet_summary: Rescuers were helping hundreds of hikers trapped by heavy snow at tourist campsites on a slope of Mount Everest in Tibet, Chinese state media said
Chinese authorities said about 350 people had made their way down but at least 200 remained stranded at the Everest Scenic Area, to the east of the mountain, on the Tibetan side of the border

items.title: Stranded Mount Everest hikers being evacuated
items.standfirst: More than 200 people left stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of Mount Everest are being evacuated, Reuters news agency reports.
items.content: More than 200 people left stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of Mount Everest are being evacuated, Reuters news agency reports.

items.title: Rescuers race to reach hundreds stranded on Mount Everest by blizzard
items.standfirst: Rescuers are racing against time to reach hundreds of stranded hikers on Mount Everest after a blizzard hit unexpectedly. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer has the very latest.
items.content: Rescuers are racing against time to reach hundreds of stranded hikers on Mount Everest after a blizzard hit unexpectedly. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer has the very latest.

items.title: Snowstorm traps hundreds of hikers on Mount Everest during China's national holiday
items.standfirst: Rescuers were helping hundreds of hikers trapped by heavy snow at tourist campsites on a slope of Mount Everest in Tibet, Chinese state media said. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Carl Cater, Associate Professor in Tourism Marketing at Swansea University, says many of the tourists caught in the storm were ill equipped and lack the outdoor skills necessary to face the challenge of hiking up the world's tallest mountain.
items.content: Rescuers were helping hundreds of hikers trapped by heavy snow at tourist campsites on a slope of Mount Everest in Tibet, Chinese state media said. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Carl Cater, Associate Professor in Tourism Marketing at Swansea University, says many of the tourists caught in the storm were ill equipped and lack the outdoor skills necessary to face the challenge of hiking up the world's tallest mountain.

items.title: Mount Everest hikers describe ‘extreme’ conditions as huge rescue effort continues
items.standfirst: At least 200 people still stranded after unseasonally heavy snowfall during China’s Golden Week holidayTrekkers have described facing “extreme” conditions after an unseasonable snowstorm during one of China’s busiest holiday weekends stranded hundreds of people on Mount Everest, prompting a massive rescue effort.Chinese authorities said about 350 people had made their way down but at least 200 remained stranded at the Everest Scenic Area, to the east of the mountain, on the Tibetan side of the border. Continue reading...
items.content: At least 200 people still stranded after unseasonally heavy snowfall during China’s Golden Week holidayTrekkers have described facing “extreme” conditions after an unseasonable snowstorm during one of China’s busiest holiday weekends stranded hundreds of people on Mount Everest, prompting a massive rescue effort.Chinese authorities said about 350 people had made their way down but at least 200 remained stranded at the Everest Scenic Area, to the east of the mountain, on the Tibetan side of the border. items.title: Watch: Race to reach hikers stranded by Mount Everest blizzard
items.standfirst: Chinese state media reports say around 350 people have been rescued and efforts are under way to reach more than 200 others.
items.content: Chinese state media reports say around 350 people have been rescued and efforts are under way to reach more than 200 others.

ai_summary: A blizzard on Mount Everest has trapped hundreds of hikers at campsites.
Rescuers are working to evacuate the stranded individuals.
At least one hiker has died due to the extreme conditions.
Many tourists were reportedly ill-equipped for the harsh conditions.
The unseasonal snowstorm occurred during China's Golden Week holiday.

clusters.title: Gaza ceasefire talks live: negotiations to continue as Israelis mark two-year anniversary of 7 October attacks
clusters.neutral_headline: Ceasefire Talks Underway Between Israel and Hamas in Egypt
bullet_summary: Rightwing members of Netanyahu’s coalition have put pressure on to ensure such popular figures remain behind bars, Israeli media has reported
Reported by Guardian World, France24, NBC World

items.title: Gaza ceasefire talks live: negotiations to continue as Israelis mark two-year anniversary of 7 October attacks
items.standfirst: The first day of Gaza talks between Hamas and mediators on Monday ended in Egypt ‘amid a positive atmosphere’, local media reportedIsrael and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza warWhile there are positive signs about this attempt to bring about an end to Israel’s war, there remains uncertainty over whether or not a deal can be secured and, crucially, maintained.Hamas has partially accepted Trump’s 20 point plan, which Israel has agreed to, but there are still major sticking points that need resolving, including the future governance of Gaza, the extent of Israel’s military withdrawal and Hamas’ disarmament.Negotiators have to agree which Palestinian prisoners will be released from Israeli jails. The Palestinian delegation is likely to ask for political figures, such as the Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouthi, who are widely popular in the West Bank and Gaza. Rightwing members of Netanyahu’s coalition have put pressure on to ensure such popular figures remain behind bars, Israeli media has reported. Continue reading...
items.content: The first day of Gaza talks between Hamas and mediators on Monday ended in Egypt ‘amid a positive atmosphere’, local media reportedIsrael and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza warWhile there are positive signs about this attempt to bring about an end to Israel’s war, there remains uncertainty over whether or not a deal can be secured and, crucially, maintained.Hamas has partially accepted Trump’s 20 point plan, which Israel has agreed to, but there are still major sticking points that need resolving, including the future governance of Gaza, the extent of Israel’s military withdrawal and Hamas’ disarmament.Negotiators have to agree which Palestinian prisoners will be released from Israeli jails. The Palestinian delegation is likely to ask for political figures, such as the Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouthi, who are widely popular in the West Bank and Gaza. Rightwing members of Netanyahu’s coalition have put pressure on to ensure such popular figures remain behind bars, Israeli media has reported. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel-Hamas ceasefire talks under way; Putin and Netanyahu discussed Trump Gaza plan, says Kremlin – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closed. You can read our latest reports here:Gaza flotilla members allege beatings and insults in Israeli detentionIsrael and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza warIran signalled its support for Trump’s Gaza plan, with the country’s foreign ministry saying it supports any initiative that brings an end to the genocide of Palestinian people.Iran’s foreign ministry wrote in a post on X:Taking into account the dangerous dimensions and aspects of this proposal, and while reiterating its warning about the repeated breaches and obstructionism by the Zionist regime in fulfilling its promises, especially in light of its expansionist and racist plans, the Islamic Republic of Iran considers any decision in this regard to be within the authority of the Palestinian people and resistance.It welcomes any decision by them that guarantees halting the genocide of Palestinians, the withdrawal of the occupying Zionist army from Gaza, respect for the Palestinian people’s right to self-determination, the entry of humanitarian aid, and the reconstruction of Gaza. Continue reading...

You can read our latest reports here:Gaza flotilla members allege beatings and insults in Israeli detentionIsrael and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza warIran signalled its support for Trump’s Gaza plan, with the country’s foreign ministry saying it supports any initiative that brings an end to the genocide of Palestinian people.Iran’s foreign ministry wrote in a post on X:Taking into account the dangerous dimensions and aspects of this proposal, and while reiterating its warning about the repeated breaches and obstructionism by the Zionist regime in fulfilling its promises, especially in light of its expansionist and racist plans, the Islamic Republic of Iran considers any decision in this regard to be within the authority of the Palestinian people and resistance.It welcomes any decision by them that guarantees halting the genocide of Palestinians, the withdrawal of the occupying Zionist army from Gaza, respect for the Palestinian people’s right to self-determination, the entry of humanitarian aid, and the reconstruction of Gaza. Continue reading...

items.title: Gaza plan needs 'awful lot of gap-filling and an implementation, enforcement mechanism'
items.standfirst: Israeli and Hamas officials are holding indirect talks in an Egyptian coastal resort on Monday on a U.S-drafted peace plan to end the war in Gaza on the eve of its second anniversary. The talks focus on the ceasefire's first stage, including the partial withdrawal of Israeli forces as well as the release of hostages held by militants in Gaza in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli detention, according to a Hamas statement. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, François Picard welcomes Nomi Bar-Yaacov, International Negotiator, Mediator, Fellow at the Global Fellowship Initiative at the Geneva Centre for Security Policy.
items.content: Israeli and Hamas officials are holding indirect talks in an Egyptian coastal resort on Monday on a U.S-drafted peace plan to end the war in Gaza on the eve of its second anniversary. The talks focus on the ceasefire's first stage, including the partial withdrawal of Israeli forces as well as the release of hostages held by militants in Gaza in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli detention, according to a Hamas statement. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, François Picard welcomes Nomi Bar-Yaacov, International Negotiator, Mediator, Fellow at the Global Fellowship Initiative at the Geneva Centre for Security Policy.

items.title: Israel and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza war
items.standfirst: Hamas’s acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between campsIsrael and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt on a US ceasefire proposal amid cautious optimism that the nearly two-year war in Gaza may be nearing its end, despite deep divisions between the two sides.Negotiations will focus on the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The three issues constitute the first phase of a 20-point plan presented by the US president, Donald Trump, last week that aims to end the war. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas’s acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between campsIsrael and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt on a US ceasefire proposal amid cautious optimism that the nearly two-year war in Gaza may be nearing its end, despite deep divisions between the two sides.Negotiations will focus on the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The three issues constitute the first phase of a 20-point plan presented by the US president, Donald Trump, last week that aims to end the war. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel and Hamas begin indirect talks in Egypt, raising hopes of ceasefire and prisoner swap
items.standfirst: Israeli, Hamas and American delegations were due in Egypt to discuss a 20-point peace plan tabled by President Donald Trump to halt the conflict.
items.content: Israeli, Hamas and American delegations were due in Egypt to discuss a 20-point peace plan tabled by President Donald Trump to halt the conflict.

ai_summary: Israel and Hamas are engaged in indirect talks in Egypt.
Negotiations are taking place amid a "positive atmosphere," according to reports.
Discussions involve the future governance of Gaza and prisoner releases.
Iran signaled support for Trump's Gaza plan, according to its foreign ministry.
Right-wing members of Netanyahu’s coalition are pressuring for prisoner restrictions.

clusters.title: ICC convicts first Darfur militia leader for war crimes
clusters.neutral_headline: ICC Convicts Darfur Militia Leader of War Crimes
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, NPR News, Guardian World

items.title: ICC convicts first Darfur militia leader for war crimes
items.standfirst: In tonight's edition, the International Criminal Court convicted the first Janjaweed militia leader for atrocities committed in Sudan's Darfur region more than 20 years ago. Also, Senegal’s Pink Lake, is increasingly drawing the attention of property developers. And Africa Week UK has its inaugural gathering amidst Britain's black history month.
items.content: In tonight's edition, the International Criminal Court convicted the first Janjaweed militia leader for atrocities committed in Sudan's Darfur region more than 20 years ago. Also, Senegal’s Pink Lake, is increasingly drawing the attention of property developers. And Africa Week UK has its inaugural gathering amidst Britain's black history month.

items.title: ICC finds former Sudan militia leader guilty of war crimes in Darfur
items.standfirst: The International Criminal Court in The Hague handed down its first-ever Darfur war crimes conviction, finding Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb, guilty of atrocities committed more than two decades ago.
items.content: The International Criminal Court in The Hague handed down its first-ever Darfur war crimes conviction, finding Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb, guilty of atrocities committed more than two decades ago.(Image credit: Koen Van Weel)

items.title: ICC convicts former Sudan militia leader for war crimes in Darfur
items.standfirst: Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, known as Ali Kushayb, found guilty over atrocitiesThe international criminal court has convicted a leader of the Janjaweed militia of playing a leading role in a campaign of atrocities committed in the Sudanese region of Darfur more than 20 years ago.It was the first time the court had convicted a suspect of crimes in Darfur. The court ruled that the atrocities, including mass murders and rapes, were part of a government plan to snuff out a rebellion in the western region of Sudan. Continue reading...
items.content: Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, known as Ali Kushayb, found guilty over atrocitiesThe international criminal court has convicted a leader of the Janjaweed militia of playing a leading role in a campaign of atrocities committed in the Sudanese region of Darfur more than 20 years ago.It was the first time the court had convicted a suspect of crimes in Darfur. The court ruled that the atrocities, including mass murders and rapes, were part of a government plan to snuff out a rebellion in the western region of Sudan. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The ICC convicted Ali Kushayb for atrocities in Darfur.
Kushayb was a Janjaweed militia leader.
The conviction is the first for Darfur war crimes.
The crimes occurred over two decades ago.
The atrocities included mass murders and rapes.

clusters.title: Who is Bari Weiss? CBS News' new editor-in-chief is a vocal critic of legacy media
clusters.neutral_headline: Bari Weiss Named CBS News Editor-in-Chief
bullet_summary: Provocative columnist Bari Weiss publicly quit the New York Times in 2020, then cofounded The Free Press as an alternative to legacy media
Paramount Skydance also acquired The Free Press, which Weiss co-founded in 2021

items.title: Who is Bari Weiss? CBS News' new editor-in-chief is a vocal critic of legacy media
items.standfirst: Provocative columnist Bari Weiss publicly quit the New York Times in 2020, then cofounded The Free Press as an alternative to legacy media. Here's what to know as she takes the helm of CBS News.
items.content: Provocative columnist Bari Weiss publicly quit the New York Times in 2020, then cofounded The Free Press as an alternative to legacy media. Here's what to know as she takes the helm of CBS News.(Image credit: Leigh Vogel)

items.title: CBS News names Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief
items.standfirst: Paramount Skydance also acquired The Free Press, which Weiss co-founded in 2021.
items.content: Bari Weiss, co-founder and CEO of The Free Press, has been appointed CBS News’ editor-in-chief, Paramount announced on Monday. The Free Press will now operate under the company as well. It’s a major move from the company, which merged with Skydance Corp. in August under CEO David Ellison. Under Ellison, the company has made several strategic acquisitions and is reportedly exploring acquiring Warner Bros. Discovery. “This move is part of Paramount’s bigger vision to modernize content and the way it connects – directly and passionately – to audiences around the world,” Ellison said in a statement. “We believe the majority of the country longs for news that is balanced and fact-based, and we want CBS to be their home.” Though she will remain CEO and editor-in-chief of The Free Press, Weiss will report directly to Ellison. The Free Press will maintain its own independent brand and operations, the company said. Weiss and her wife, Nellie Bowles, launched The Free Press in 2021 with Weiss’ sister Suzy. She was previously an opinion writer for The New York Times. Partnering with Paramount, Weiss said, allows The Free Press to expand its audience of 1.5 million. “The values that we’ve hammered out here over the years—journalism based in curiosity and honesty, a culture of healthy disagreement, our shared belief in America’s promise—now have the opportunity to go very, very big,” Weiss wrote in a blog post on The Free Press. Earlier this year, CBS and Paramount settled a $16 million lawsuit with President Donald Trump over a “60 Minutes” interview with then-Vice President Kamala Harris. Paramount then hired an ombudsman to analyze bias in CBS reporting. Weiss said she believes in Ellison and “the entire leadership team who took over Paramount this summer.” She added that they plan to make CBS “the most trusted news organization of the 21st Century.”

ai_summary: Bari Weiss is the new editor-in-chief of CBS News.
She is a vocal critic of legacy media.
Weiss co-founded The Free Press.
Paramount Skydance acquired The Free Press.
Weiss has no broadcast television experience.
